<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of mutex:
```c
static int mutex(void)
{
	metal_mutex_t lock;
	const int threads = 10;
	int rc;

	metal_mutex_init(&lock);

	rc = metal_run(threads, mutex_thread, &lock);

	metal_mutex_deinit(&lock);

	return rc;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function mutex:
typedef struct {
	atomic_int v;
} metal_mutex_t
...
int metal_run(int threads, metal_thread_t child, void *arg)
{
	pthread_t tids[threads];
	int error, ts_created;

	error = metal_run_noblock(threads, child, arg, tids, &ts_created);

	metal_finish_threads(ts_created, (void *)tids);

	return error;
}
...
static void *mutex_thread(void *arg)
{
	metal_mutex_t *l = arg;
	int i;

	for (i = 0; i < mutex_test_count; i++) {
		metal_mutex_acquire(l);
		usleep(1);
		metal_mutex_release(l);
	}

	return NULL;
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
rc = metal_run(threads, mutex_thread, &lock);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the pointer refers to a mutable metal_mutex_t object that is modified by the thread (metal_mutex_acquire/metal_mutex_release), so it must be a pointer to non-const. metal_run and mutex_thread use void * / metal_mutex_t * and perform non-const operations, so const qualification is not appropriate here. (A violation would occur if the code treated the object as immutable but used a non-const pointer — e.g. passing a pointer to data that is not modified but not declaring the parameter as pointer-to-const.)
